children.text: Thought by Dutch architects with more than 40 years of experience, ikwoon is a free web app to inform Dutch private landlords of the best renovation practices. According to their specific typology of building, personal priorities, and budget, users can receive a simple and bespoke renovation plan.
I was mostly in charge of the rebranding and UI design of the app and website. I closely collaborated with
Hugo Pilate
, the UX designer and project manager coordinating the whole project including the development.
Later on, I also updated their existing WordPress website with the new identity and content.

Bruxxx is a recommendation map and list for guests staying at an Airbnb in Brussels (Schaerbeek). Categories and references were defined after 3 years of guests’ questions and reviews of the neighborhood. The website link is printed on the wall of the Airbnb lounge.
The website was built with next.js, react.js, mapbox API and deployed on GitHub page.
A straightforward and smooth list that gives the largest visibility to images.
Easy to maintain, this website is connected to one of Jozef’s Vimeo playlists so he can update it in a few clicks.
This website was developed with node.js, express.js, react.js, CSS, and Vimeo API. Also with the back-end courses of Kevin Tassi.
The project is a service-oriented appointment system meant to spread patients' reservations evenly, as practitioners don't all have the same availabilities, yet similar skills.
The visual identity was developed around the idea of stress points and fluidity.
This website was developed with HTML, CSS, PHP, and Simplybookme API.
An intranet for the international sales team of Terumo to share thoughts, documents, and guidelines.
Along with a project manager and another UX/UI designer, we ran co-creative sessions with the concerned users to design the best digital architecture and interface for their daily needs.

node.title: Video-making app for promoting green electricity
node.excerpt: The World Bank (with Quicksand Design Studio)

children.text: The project is a digital platform for community engagement in communities with either existing mini-grids or intending to adopt grids. The goal was to further learning and awareness about green electricity in North India. Through a simple app, any user could record their story about how the grid changed their life.

My role was to conduct desk and field research, such as writing protocols, visiting users, and interviewing experts. Then ultimately translating research synthesis into a usable product. I worked in a team of 7 people (design researchers, graphic designer, developer, project manager, and movie-maker). I mostly enjoyed observing users and figuring out the structure of the app.

node.title: Connected city lights for another mobility

children.text: A city light suggesting physical exercises integrated into citizens' daily routes. Via an application, users can change parameters and receive bespoke exercises. Rather focused on physical maintenance than improvement, exercises offer another way to envision urban motion and physical activity. No levels, no numbers, no comparison, and no statistics. Just an unobtrusive light to deviate from our daily paths.

I spent a year reading all about physical activity in public spaces, contemporary dance, and urban design. I interviewed 12 experts (an urban planner, a light engineer, a fitness teacher...) and also collaborated with a physiotherapist, an animation designer, a video maker, and a few dancers.
